dataset.title: MCR LTER: Coral Reef: Growth and scaling of photosynthetic energy intake in Fungia concinna: Elahi & Edmunds 2007 JEMBE

address.deliveryPoint: Department of Biology, California State University

abstract.para: For many marine invertebrates, the maximum size of an individual is influenced heavily by environmental factors and may be limited by energetic constraints. In this study, an energetic model developed originally for anemones was applied to the free-living scleractinian Fungia concinna (Verrill) from Moorea, French Polynesia to test the hypothesis that energetic constraints limit the size of this solitary coral. The modified model assumed that photosynthesis was the primary source of metabolic energy, and that metabolic costs were represented by aerobic respiration; these sources and sinks of energy were compared using daily energy budgets that were analyzed using double logarithmic regressions of energy against coral size.

These data were published in Elahi, R. and P.J. Edmunds. 2007. Determinate growth and the scaling of photosynthetic energy intake in the solitary coral Fungia concinna (Verrill). Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology 349:183-193. and were part of the masters thesis of R. Elahi (2005).

keywordSet.keyword: Richard B. Gump South Pacific Research Station

intellectualRights.para:
Data collected under the auspices of the MCR LTER are available to the public after primary publication, or at most two years after the completion of the study unless proprietary restrictions are warranted. Use of MCR LTER data is subject to acceptance of the following conditions:
1. The user agrees to provide valid name and contact information prior to downloading online data. This information will be used to contact the user in case of changes to the data, and may also be used by data set authors and MCR LTER project administrators to document data usage.
2. The user agrees to cite the data set author and MCR LTER in all publications in which the data are used, as per the instructions in the data documentation. If no specific instructions are provided in the data documentation, the user is requested to include the following statement: "Data sets were provided by the Moorea Coral Reef Ecosystem LTER, funded by the US National Science Foundation (OCE-0417412 & OCE-1026851)."
3. The user agrees to provide one copy of any manuscript based on MCR LTER data to the data set author prior to submitting it for publication.
4. The user agrees to send two hard copies of any published manuscript based on MCR LTER data to the following address: Dr. Andrew J. Brooks Deputy Program Director, MCR LTER Marine Science Institute University of California Santa Barbara, CA 93106-6150 The user also agrees to send one electronic copy (pdf format) to the following e-mail address: brooks@msi.ucsb.edu
5. Users are prohibited from selling or redistributing any data provided by MCR LTER without explicit prior permission.
6. Users are encouraged to contact original investigators responsible for data. Where appropriate, researchers whose projects are integrally dependent on MCR LTER data are encouraged to consider collaboration and/or co-authorship with original investigators.
7. Extensive efforts are made to ensure that online data are accurate and up to date, but the authors and the MCR LTER will not take responsibility for any errors that may exist in data provided online. Furthermore, the user assumes all responsibility for errors in analysis or judgment resulting from use of the data.
8. Any violation of the terms of this agreement will result in immediate forfeiture of the data and loss of access privileges to other MCR LTER data sets.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: North shore study area for Elahi thesis

contact.positionName: Information Manager, Moorea Coral Reef LTER

section.para: Methods from: Elahi, R. and P.J. Edmunds. 2007. Determinate growth and the scaling of photosynthetic energy intake in the solitary coral Fungia concinna (Verrill). Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology 349:183-193.
Methods from Chapter 4 of: Elahi, R. 2006. Effects of age and size on the growth and physiology of scleractinian corals. MS Thesis, California State University Northridge, Northridge, CA.

protocol.title: CHAPTER 4 Energetic constraints on indeterminate growth in the solitary coral, Fungia concinna

section.title: Methods excerpts from Chapter 4 of R. Elahi masters thesis and Elahi & Edmunds 2007 JEMBE.
section.para: Fungia concinna was chosen to test the energetic constraints on growth because it attains the smallest maximum size of congenerics (F. scutaria, F. paumotensis, F. repanda, F. fungites) present on the north coast of Moorea (17o 28.528' S, 149o 49.970' W), French Polynesia (Veron 2000; pers. obs.), where this study was completed. The habitat studied is typical of forereef slopes on Moorea's north coast (Adjeroud et al., 2002) with scleractinian corals as the dominant space occupiers, especially the genera Acropora, Pocillopora, Montipora and Porites (pers. obs.).

Fungia concinna were sampled from a forereef buttress at 15 - 16 m depth for the scaling analyses required for the energetic model. ... The scaling of energetic cost and intake was quantified as aerobic respiration and photosynthesis, respectively. ... The energetic cost associated with growth was quantified using the physiological traits necessary to construct a growth budget, namely, calcification rates, Symbiodinium population density, and tissue biomass (Davies 1984, Edmunds & Davies 1986). Lastly, at the study site, light levels were measured for the calculation of daily energetic intake from photosynthesis, and the population size structure of F. concinna was quantified to provide a context for the energetic model.

section.title: Respiration and photosynthesis
section.para: The effects of flow on mass transfer-dependent processes such as respiration and photosynthesis have been well-studied in benthic marine organisms (Carpenter et al. 1991, Patterson et al. 1991, Sebens et al. 2003). For example, in low flow environments mass transfer may be limited, thus potentially reducing the metabolic rates of corals (Bruno & Edmunds 1998). The nature of the flow environment around an organism can be characterized using the Reynolds number, Re (Denny 1988), a dimensionless ratio of the inertial and viscous forces acting upon an organism: Re = (UL)ν-1 where U is the velocity of the fluid relative to the organism, L is a characteristic linear dimension of the organism, and ν is the kinematic viscosity of the fluid. Inertial forces are related to the product of the flow speed and the organism size, thus organisms of varying size experience different flow environments in the same flow speed. Because the present study addressed the effects of coral size on energetic cost (respiration) and intake (photosynthesis), the metabolic trials were designed to create a uniform flow environment for corals of varying size by adjusting the absolute flow speeds.

section.title: Zooxanthellae, chlorophyll and biomass
section.para: After oxygen flux trials, corals were kept in flow-through aquaria (<7 days) before removing the tissue with a Waterpik(R) (Johannes and Wiebe, 1970) containing filtered seawater (0.45 μm; FSW), to produce a slurry that subsequently was homogenized. The Symbiodinium density in the slurry was determined using a 1 ml aliquot in which the cells were concentrated by centrifugation (13,000 rpm), resuspended, and counted (n = 10) using a hemocytometer.... To assess the scaling of chlorophyll a content, pigment concentrations were estimated within 3 weeks of freezing (-4 C) the tissue slurry.... 12 freshly-collected F. concinna (6.2-69.4 cm2) were used to assess the relationship between tissue biomass and size. Corals were fixed in 5% formalin in seawater for 24 h, decalcified in 10% HCl for 24-48 h, and the resulting tissue tunics dried (60 C for 7 days) and weighed (Edmunds and Davies, 1986).

section.title: Calcification and skeletal characteristics
section.para: Corals (n = 28; 6.2-95.9 cm2) were collected from the study site and weighed (+-1 mg) in seawater using the buoyant weight method (Davies, 1989) to examine if weight scaled proportionately with surface area. To calculate calcification rates, corals were tagged using small plastic squares (0.5 cm2) that were epoxied (Z-spar(R) Splash Zone A-788) to the aboral surface, and then placed back at the study site.... After 25 days (10 February-6 March 2005) the change in buoyant weight was converted to dry skeletal weight using equations from Davies (1989), assuming the density of aragonite to be 2.93 mg cm-3.

section.title: Field photon flux density
section.para: The PFD at the study site was quantified using a LiCor LI-193SA spherical quantum sensor deployed at 15 m depth from 11:48 am to 12:01 pm on 27 February 2005, a day with clear skies. PFD was measured every 5 s and the average reading for each minute was used as a statistical replicate for calculating the percent transmittance of surface PFD to 15 m. To characterize daily light conditions at the study site, surface PFD was measured using a spherical quantum sensor and logged (LiCor Li-1000) continu- ously from 1 March to 13 March 2005. PFD was measured every minute, and the mean PFD over half-hour intervals was converted to in situ PFD using the mean percentage of light transmitted to 15 m depth....

section.title: Energy budget calculations
section.para: Net photosynthetic rates for each half-hour interval were converted to energy (J) by assuming that 6 mol of oxygen resulted in the formation of 1 mol of glucose, with an energy equivalent of 2817 kJ (Lehninger, 1973). The resulting values were summed over 12.5 h (the day length in the austral summer) to give the integrated net energetic intake. Respiratory oxygen consumption was converted to energetic cost using the oxy-joule equivalent of 19.63 J ml O2-1 (Elliot and Davison, 1975), assuming that lipid is the main respiratory substrate (Patton et al., 1977). The daily net energetic intake was added to the energetic cost over 12.5 h to give the daily gross energetic intake....

dataTable.entityDescription: The photon flux density (pfd) data from 1-13 March 2005 which is plotted in Figure 2 of Elahi & Edmunds 2007. These data were collected on land, and PAR at 15 m depth was calculated by multiplying land PFD by 0.055 (% transmittance to 15 m depth).

attribute.attributeDefinition: Time of day in Moorea local time.
Date of Observation as YYYY-MM-DD
Photon flux density (PFD) of light within the range of Photosyntehtically active radiation (PAR) calculated for 15 m depth from data collected on land.

dataTable.entityDescription: Surface area and mass of each of nine sucessful trials used to plot the P-I curve in Figure 2 (inset) of Elahi & Edmunds 2007.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Coral ID number matching the Photosynthesis Irradiance table.
Surface area is the calculated circular area (cm2) of the oral surface from the average of two diameter measurements.
Tissue is the predicted tissue weight of each coral (based on a regression of tissue weight and surface area from 12 sacrificed.)

dataTable.entityDescription: Oxygen evolution data for each photosynthesis irradiance from nine successful trials used to plot the P-I curve in Figure 2 (inset) of Elahi & Edmunds 2007.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Coral ID number matching the Surface Area and Mass table.
Photosynthetically available radiation photon flux density (PAR PFD) at seven levels.
Oxygen evolution for each irradiance level.

dataTable.entityDescription: Zooxanthellae counts and chlorophyll content for 12 corals used in Figure 3 of Elahi & Edmunds 2007.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Coral ID number.
Surface area is the calculated circular area (cm2) of the oral surface from the average of two diameter measurements.
The count of zooxanthellae per coral.
The amount (μg) of chlorophyll per coral.

dataTable.entityDescription: Tissue mass data for 12 corals used in Figure 3 of Elahi & Edmunds 2007.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Coral ID number.
Measured tissue weight (mg) of each coral.

dataTable.entityDescription: Skeletal weight and calcification data for 26 corals used in Figure 3 of Elahi & Edmunds 2007.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Coral ID letter (A through Z).
Measured length of first of two perpendicular diameters.
Measured length of second of two perpendicular diameters.
Initial air skeletal weight as determined using the bouyant weight technique prior to the growth period.
Final air skeletal weight as determined using the bouyant weight technique at the end of the growth period.
Skeletal weight growth rate in mg per day.
Any conditions to be noted.

dataTable.entityDescription: Daily estimates of energy cost and intake for each coral used in the Figure 4 inset of Elahi & Edmunds 2007. (See methods for calculation details.)

attribute.attributeDefinition: Coral ID number.
Surface area is the calculated circular area (cm2) of the oral surface from the average of two diameter measurements.
Tissue is the predicted tissue weight of each coral (based on a regression of tissue weight and surface area from 12 sacrificed corals.)
Gross photosynthetic intake (J/day) of Zooanthellae.
Daily energy cost of zooxanthellae respiration.
Daily energy cost of zooxanthellae growth.
Energy translocated from zooxanthellae to the animal host on a daily basis.
Daily energy cost of coral respiration.
Daily energy cost of coral growth.
Summed daily cost of growth and respiration (of the holobiont).
Summed daily cost of respiration only (of the holobiont).

dataTable.entityDescription: Mean length and surface area data for the histogram in Figure 4 of Elahi & Edmunds 2007.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Mean length is the average of two diameter measurements (taken perpendicular to each other.)
Surface area is the calculated circular area (cm2) of the oral surface from the average of two diameter measurements.
